Problem:
Consider a complex function \\( z(t) = x(t) + iy(t) \\), evolving over time governed by the differential equation \\( \\dot{z} = Pz \\), where \\( P \\) is a constant matrix. The transformation defined by \\( g(z) = e^{Qt}z \\) with another constant matrix \\( Q \\) is applied to assess various impacts on the function.

If \\( g(z) \\) is applied to an initial condition \\( z_0 \\) at t = 0, and then allowed to evolve under \\( \\dot{z} = Pz \\) without further intervention, will \\( z(T) \\) at t = T be the same as if \\( z_0 \\) was directly evolved to t = T under \\( \\dot{z} = Pz \\)?
Explanation: The application of \\( g(z) \\) modifies the initial condition by transforming \\( z_0 \\) into \\( e^{QT}z_0 \\) at t = 0. This change in initial condition means that \\( z(t) \\) will evolve differently under \\( \\dot{z} = Pz \\), depending on the relationship between matrices P and Q, leading to a distinct state at time T.
